EXECUTIVE  SUMMARY 

A.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response

Chelan Fruit Cooperative, (hereafter referred to as CFC) accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices.  It is the policy of CFC to adhere to all applicable federal and state safety and environmental regulations.

	CFC refrigeration personnel do respond to ammonia releases and have received training in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.120, in addition to training specifically for ammonia.  An emergency plan has been developed covering notification to public safety agencies and the public.  An evacuation plan for the plant has also been developed and all employees receive training on this plan.

At CFC anhydrous ammonia is used on-site. Ammonia is considered hazardous by EPA and is listed on the Extremely Hazardous Substance (EHS) list.  Chemical properties of ammonia make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling ammonia in order to:

¿	Prevent unnecessary human exposure
¿	Reduce the threat to our personnel
¿	Reduce the threat to the community


B.	Facility and Regulated Substance Handled

CFC is a group of fruit processing and cold storage facilities, located near the city of Chelan, county of Chelan, city of Pateros / Brewster and Okanogan, county of Okanogan, state of Washington.

The regulated substance used at CFC is anhydrous ammonia (CAS # 7664-41-7).

systems.  The largest interconnected system could potentially involve Engine Room
1 and #2, and potentially release 8,570 pounds of product.

There is approximately 17,655 pounds of anhydrous ammonia in the Pateros North 
system. The larger of the two independent systems ( South Engine Room ) could
potentially release 10,009 pounds of product.
There  is  approximately  2,169 pounds  of  anhydrous ammonia  in the Pateros
South system. The quantities present at this location are well below the 10,000
pound threshold and therefore does not require a RMP.  As such, Worst Case and
Alternative Scenarios were not calculated.  If in the future this location increases it¿s
capacity to the 10,000 threshold an amended RMP will be immediately submitted. 
In order to provide the Pateros South facility and the surrounding area a higher 
level of safety, most components of this RMP and related PSM are applied to the
Pateros South facility.

There is approximately 23,827 pounds of anhydrous ammonia in the Okanogan
systems. The largest interconnected system could potentially involve Engine Room

CFC uses other hazardous substances on-site, however they do not meet or exceed the threshold limits established in 40 CFR 68.130.  However, CFC believes in the concept set forth in the ¿General Duty Clause¿ of the Clean Air Act.  To this effect, CFC has established policies, procedures and training to reduce the risk of an accidental hazardous substance release for the safety of its employees and surrounding areas.


C.  Worst-Case and Alternative Scenarios

The off-site consequence analysis considers two ammonia release scenarios identified as ¿worst case¿ and ¿alternative¿ scenarios.

The worst case scenario is defined by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), which states that ¿the owner or operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released.  The alternative scenario is defined as ¿more likely to occur than the worst case scenario¿.

Worst-Case Scenario Chelan - Failure of the largest interconnected vessels in the Chelan facility would release 12,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The release would occur inside the compressor room; its walls are in direct contact with the outside, however the effects of building mitigation were not considered.  

The distance to the toxic end-point of 0.14 mg/L is 1.8 mile.  The ¿risk radius¿ extends past the boundaries of the plant, into public receptor areas. Distance was determined by use of RMP-COMP.

It was, however, assumed that the safeties and computer control would limit the release to the amount in the receiver.

All of the above ¿worst-case¿ and ¿alternative¿ scenarios are unlikely due to the safeties on the system such as temperature and pressure cutouts, computer controls and pressure relief valves to prevent an overpressure situation.

A more realistic scenario would be that of a pressure relief valve lifting, discharging ammonia vapor from vents on top of the building, approximately 40 feet above the ground.  In scenarios modeled for this type of an event, the risk radius was reduced to approximately 250 yards.

HAZARD  ASSESSMENT

This hazard assessment was prepared in compliance with Subpart B of 40 CFR 68.

Applicability

CFC uses ammonia as a refrigerant for cold storage of fresh fruit. Ammonia is an EPA-regulated substance and the amount onsite is in excess of the regulatory threshold of 10,000 pounds.  The use of ammonia at CFC is subject to Washington State and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations. The worst case scenario¿s risk radius does encompass public and environmental receptors.  This qualifies CFC as a Program 3 facility.

Offsite Consequence Analysis Parameters (68.22)

The following parameters were used when determining the offsite consequences, as required by Section 68.22.

End-point - Toxic

As required by the EPA, the toxic end-point of 0.14mg/L was used as the end-point for the worst case scenario.  It was also used for the alternative scenario.  Distances to the end-point for the worst-case scenario were computed by use of RMP-COMP¿, version 1.06.  The toxic end-point determined was:

Chelan		1.8 miles
Pateros North	1.6 miles
Brewster		1.3 miles
Okanogan		1.12 miles

No passive mitigation was used in the calculation for the toxic end-point. The toxic end-point of 0.14mg/L (or 200 ppm) is the concentration at which an average person can be exposed to for up to an hour without adverse health effects.

The toxic end-point of 0.14 mg/L for the alternative scenario was computed by the use of Aerial Location of Hazardous Atmosphere (ALOHA¿), version 5.2.1.  ALOHA¿ modeling a toxic end-point of:

Chelan		1,100 yards
Pateros North	  918  yards
Brewster		   779 yards
Okanogan		   684 yards

All of the above facility locations were based on a release directly to atmosphere. 

Wind Speed/Atmospheric Stability Class

For the worst-case release analysis, as required by EPA, a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second and F atmospheric stability class were used for all facilities.

For the alternative release scenario, a wind speed of 3 meters per second, and stability class D were used for all facilities.


Ambient Temperature/Humidity

For the worst-case release analysis, as required by EPA, a temperature of 25 degrees centigrade and humidity of 50% were used.

For the alternative release scenario, a temperature of 51 degrees Fahrenheit (Annual mean temperature) and 25% humidity were used. [Climatological Summary Table (1940 ¿ 1993), Tree Fruit Research Center, Wenatchee, WA, - National Weather Service.]

Height of Release

For the worst-case release analysis, as required by EPA, the release was analyzed assuming ground level (0 feet) release.

For the alternative release analysis, the release was again analyzed assuming ground level.  This was based on a release from a .75¿ in diameter short pipe, at the bottom of the receiver, below the liquid line at all facilities.

Surface Roughness

Rural surface roughness was chosen for both scenarios in all facility locatgions.  The selection was based on the fact that the surrounding area within a 1-mile radius is has ver

y few buildings and is fairly open at all locations.

Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis (68.25)

RMP regulation requires that a worst-case release scenario analysis be performed for each substance in excess of the regulatory threshold.  Since ammonia is the only substance on site in excess of the threshold, only one worst-case scenario was performed.  

The quantity calculated for Chelan was the amount in the largest vessel, as required by 40 CFR 68.25(e), which is the high-pressure receiver.  The dimensions of the receiver are 4.5¿ in circumference and 20¿ in length, giving the receiver a volume of 318 cubic feet.  The amount of ammonia possible, if the vessel were to be filled to 100% capacity at 85 degrees F is 11,845 pounds. (Based on the weight of liquid ammonia at 85o F, which is 37.25 pounds per cubic foot.)  Since there is connecting piping to the receiver containing liquid ammonia, the actual amount used in modeling the worst-case release was 12,000 pounds.  Also, there are no administrative controls or passive mitigation used in this scenario to mitigate the effects of the release. The distance to the toxic end-point, of 1.8 mile, was obtained by use of RMP-COMP, version 1.06.


Alternative Release Scenario Analysis (68.28)

RMP regulations require that at least one alternative scenario be identified and analysis for each regulated substance, at each location.  Since ammonia is the only regulated substance in excess of the threshold, only one alternative scenario was selected.  The scenario used was a release from a short pipe (.75¿ diameter) at the bottom of the receiver (the drain).  Of the alternative scenarios looked at, this scenario gave the greatest risk radius for the alternative release.

Using ALOHA¿, the modeling analysis was based on the high-pressure receiver being filled with 30% liquid at 85o F, which is the normal operating situation.  The tank-modeling source was used, which resulted in a Chelan risk radius of 1,100 yards, Pateros North

at 918  yards, Brewster at 779 yards and Okanogan at 684 yards.  The tank and heavy gas model was used for each alternative scenario location .

[It should be noted that the most realistic (and common) alternative release scenario would be from the lifting of a pressure relief valve (PRV), venting ammonia vapor to atmosphere.  In the models run with this scenario, none of the release scenarios from a PRV produced a risk radius in excess of the chosen alternative scenario.  Other alternative scenarios ran produced risk radiuses between 225 yards and 500 yards, based on a toxic end-point of 0.14 mg/L]

Process Safety Information (68.65)

Anhydrous ammonia is the chemical used in the refrigeration process and is the chemical used at CFC that requires Process Safety Management. This requires CFC to be a Program 3 for RMP purposes.

Exposures to anhydrous ammonia tend to happen suddenly and unexpectedly.  Situations where exposure can occur include:
¿	During transfer from shipping vehicle to system.
¿	When equipment fails.
¿	When pressure release valve opens.
¿	When equipment is damaged.

The following is the basic process safety information for anhydrous ammonia.  Complete Process Safety Information can be found in CFC¿s Process Safety Management document, located in the refrigeration office.

Physical Data

Description:  Anhydrous ammonia is a hydroscopic compound, which means that it seeks water from the nearest source, including the human body (ammonia in the eyes can cause blindness).  It is a colorless gas with a pungent, suffocating odor.  It is shipped as a liquefied compressed gas.  It is easily liquefied under pressure.  Its chemical symbol is NH3.

Molecular Weight:  17.0

Boiling Point:  -28 F 

Freezing Point:  -108 F

Specific Gravity:  0.68  

Vapor Density:  0.6

Vapor Pressure:  8.5 atmospheres

Upper Flammable Limit (UFL):  27%

Lower Flammable Limit (LFL):  16%  [note - the LFL may be lower with the presence of oil in the ammonia]

Expansion Ratio:  850 to 1

Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapor Explosion (B

LEVE):  Flame impingement on a pressure vessel has the potential of causing a BLEVE.

Special:  Although ammonia does not meet the US Department of Transportation (DOT) definition of a flammable gas (for labeling purposes), it should be treated as one. 

Special:  Ammonia decomposes into nitrogen and hydrogen above 600o F.


Toxicity Data and Exposure Limits

Description:  Ammonia is considered an Extremely Hazardous Substance (EHS) by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

Threshold Limit Value-Time Weighted Average (TLV-TWA):  25 ppm

Short Term Exposure Limit (STEL):  35 ppm

Immediately Dangerous to Life & Health (IDLH):  300 ppm

Routes of Exposure:  Inhalation; skin & eye contact

Target Organs:  Eyes, skin, and respiratory system.

Symptoms:  Irritation of eyes, nose and/or throat.  Dyspnea (breathing difficulty, bronchospasm, chest pain, pulmonary edema (fluid in the lungs), pink frothy sputum, skin burns, and frostbite from liquid ammonia.  

Health: Ammonia can do severe damage to the eyes, exposure to amounts above 700 ppm can cause permanent eye damage.  At 50,000 ppm death is immediate.  Ammonia¿s ability to bond with water destroys any human tissue (since all tissue has moisture).

Incompatibilities and Reactivates

Anhydrous Ammonia is incompatible with:  acids; aldehydes; amides, halogens, heavy metals, oxidizers, plastics, and sulfur.

At CFC, the ammonia is used in a closed system, so the threat of ammonia mixing with an incompatible material is minimal.  It is important to keep potential incompatible materials away from areas that have the highest potential of a release, such as pressure relief devices.

Ammonia is stable and hazardous polymerization will not occur.

Corrosiveness

Anhydrous Ammonia is corrosive to certain materials, including brass, bronze, copper, cuprous nickel, nickel copper, phosphor bronze, tin, and zinc.  It is also corrosive to human tissue.

Iron and steel are suitable for use with ammonia, if iron contamination i

s not a problem.  Rusting will occur, particularly in the vapor space of tanks, but the attack diminishes with time as the vessel becomes ¿seasoned¿.

Solutions of ammonia and ammonium nitrate (used for fertilizers) are intensely corrosive to carbon steel, even at ambient temperatures.  Corrosion can be reduced by the use of an inhibitor.
	
Ammonia increases corrosion in nitrate solutions and solutions of other acid-forming anions because acidic constituents are formed upon hydrolysis, and because of the ability of the ammonium ion to form complexes with iron in steel.

V	PROCESS DESCRIPTION

A	Anhydrous Ammonia ( NH3 ) is commonly used as an effective refrigerant in cold storage facilities .  The type of refrigeration system used is a ¿flooded¿ system, using a float switch and an electric operating solenoid valve for liquid level control and a back pressure regulator to control temperature.  In this process the liquid refrigerant flows from the liquid receiver through the liquid line, up to the electrically oper

ated solenoid valve.  The evaporator in this system consists of a tubed coil.  It contains an electric solenoid valve, which maintains a constant level of liquid refrigerant under a low-side pressure. Vaporized refrigerant moves through the suction (vapor) line to the compressor where it is compressed to a high pressure and discharged into the condenser.  It is cooled by the condenser, returns to a liquid and flows into the liquid receiver.  There is currently, approximately 28,000 pounds of NH3 on the Chelan site, 17,655 pounds on the Pateros North site, 23,215 pounds on the Brewster site and 23,827 pounds on the Okanogan site.  The Pateros South and Omak facilities owned and operated by CFC use NH3 but lack sufficient inventory to require their inclusion into this plan at this time.

B	Personal Protective Equipment ( PPE )

1.	Small gaseous releases ( such as oil change problems ) shall require at least gloves and goggles and the notification of another co-worker to respond and standby with similar PPE. 

2.	Any release larger than referenced above shall require Level B body protection with SCBA, nitrile gloves and nitrile rubber boots if this level is chosen then the 2-in/2-out rule applies. The Fire Departments are equipped to provide the two out for rescue purposes only.

3.	If aerosol or liquid NH3 is present, the hazardous materials response team shall not enter for any reason.


C	Discovery Phase

1.	Before any emergency situations, employees shall know the location of their primary and secondary emergency exits and evacuation assembly areas.  Remember the way you entered may not be the best way to exit in an emergency. 

2.	Upon discovering any accidental NH3 release, immediately summon assistance via a supervisor via the cell phone or radio, and rescue anyone (including yourself) who is in immediate danger from the NH3, if safe to do so.
3.	Remove any victims to the closest "safe area", while simultaneously notifying other employees to evacuate the area. 

4.	If the supervisor determines that a true NH3 release emergency exists then all non response plan employees will evac

uate the facilities buildings as provided in the Emergency Evacuation Plan.

5.	If a rescue is deemed necessary and the Fire Department is responding, they can use their Positive Pressure Fan ( PPV ) to reduce the concentration of the NH3 gas and improve rescue capabilities. 


D	Initial Stage

1	Handling Releases of  NH3

			The small spill criteria shall include all of the following:

?	Less than 100 pounds of product
?	PPM less than 300
?	Not leaking rapidly
?	Product doesn't endanger people except by direct contact 
?	Product doesn't endanger the environment due to the vaporization process.
?	Can be managed safely by trained employees 
?	Will not spread to or affect off-site locations.

2	Emergency Actions

¿	Activate the Emergency Evacuation process.

¿	Under the emergency response plan, employees may respond only to small releases or releases that can be handled without entering the danger area. 

¿	Establish Hot and Cold Zones

¿	PPE (primarily the level of respiratory protection) requirements shall be established by the Senior Facility Refrigeration Lead, based on observed incident severity.



¿	Very small releases may be stopped by any direct action necessary on the leaking component. (Releases at valve packing would meet this criteria.)

¿	Releases of NH3 into areas that are suspect or proven to be Inherently Dangerous to Life and Health ( IDLH ) should be approached by indirect or remote operational methods such as closing valves and/or turning off equipment safely outside the Hot Zone.

¿	A compressor room exposed to an unplanned NH3 release should be ventilated using the existing ventilation equipment.  Arriving Fire Department apparatus could use PPV to assist the Engine Room ventilation system.  

¿	If it is impossible to sufficiently isolate and stop a small release, then it may be necessary to remotely pump down a section of piping or equipment, to stop the leak.

.

I	Shelter in Place

1.	This is a viable and safe option to evacuation in certain situations for the surrounding residences, neighboring businesses and CFC employees. It can be taken during an ammonia release to protect personnel from the ammonia vapor.  This procedure can be especially useful for the main office.  The idea is to have personnel stay inside of a building and close doors and windows, keeping the ammonia vapor out of the building.  Shelter-in-Place can be used by the EM calling for it during an emergency evacuation process, or if it is safer for employees to stay inside instead of evacuating through an ammonia release.  Upon being notified to take Shelter-in-Place, the following should be done:

¿	Move to an area inside with the fewest doors and windows.  A room in the center of the building is best.

¿	Shut all doors and windows, but do not lock doors.

¿	Turn off any external air circulating equipment or turn HVAC controls to 100% internal circulation.

¿	Seal off bottom of doors with towels, newspaper, tape, or any other item that will help keep ammonia vapors out.

¿	Account for personnel and notify the EM, by radio if everyone is accounted for, or if there are personnel not accounted for.


¿	Remain inside until directed by the EM, or designee, that it is safe to leave.

¿	After it is safe to leave, open up the area and let the area air   out.

Size Up

 On a drawing of the area indicate the following:
	1.	Probable spill location.
	2.	Safest point of entry.
	3.	Routes of exit once inside.
	4.	Delineate the hot zone.
	5.	Locate the command post.
	6.	Locate decontamination areas.

Action

	1.	Move equipment to an area that is not affected by the release (the cold zone). This includes all self-contained breathing apparatus, PPE, ropes, flashlights, drinking liquids, materials for decontamination, fans, first aid supplies, ladders, tools, etc.
	2.	Equip two responders with SCBA, PPE and sampling equipment and have them take a sample just inside the doorway to the release area.
	3.	Based on the reading, the type of protective clothing that is required can be determined. (If the chemical is harmful to the skin, chemical suit protection is required.)
	4.	If the reading is less than 1/4 of the LEL for that chemical (in the case of ammonia this will be 4%), the two responders can enter and search for the spill or leak. Readings should be taken every 20 feet and if at any time the readings approach 4%, the responders are to exit immediately.
	5.	Equip a third responder and have him stay at the edge of the hot zone and man the rope attached to one of the two responders.
	6.	Confirm ventilat

ion has automatically started.
	7.	After the release site has been secured, the responders will exit and go to the decontamination area.
